article.headline: New Mexico 56, TCU 54
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- New Mexico got its 20th straight win at home with an unlikely cast of playmakers -- a freshman from Australia, a guard trying to work his way out of the coach's doghouse and a slow-footed official. Point guards Darren Prentice and Ryan Kersten hit key 3-pointers down the stretch and New Mexico held TCU scoreless over the final four minutes to take a 56-54 win Wednesday night. New Mexico (11-5, 2-1 MWC) extended the nation's fifth longest homecourt winning streak to 20 games, but only after it rallied from a seven-point deficit late in the second half. The Lobos then survived a flurry of last second shots by the Horned Frogs (4-12, 0-2 MWC) that could have won the game or forced overtime. "I was concerned, but Kersten made some huge plays," New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay said. Nile Murry led the Frogs with 18 points. TCU nearly pulled off the win by hitting 8 3-pointers. But the Frogs, who shot just 32.7 percent for the game, couldn't get a shot to fall at the end. "We had several chance and if one of them goes, we win the game," TCU coach Neil Dougherty said. "You have to understand how razor-thin it can be." The Frogs tried to protect their shrinking lead by running a patient halfcourt offense in the final four minutes, but they couldn't get their shots to fall. "We were trying to get a weave or penetration type thing to try to catch them either falling asleep on the backline where we could throw the ball or give someone else a jumpshot," Dougherty said. "We got the jumpshot every time, we just couldn't get one to fall." Kersten, the freshman from Australia, broke a 54-54 tie on a layup with 1:58 left. Kersten rebounded a missed shot by Murry, raced down the court and wedged his way through a couple of TCU players to hit what turned out to be the final points of the night. TCU's Neiman Owens missed a 3-pointer with 30 seconds left but the Frogs rebounded the miss and called a time-out. When play resumed Murry misfired on a 2-point shot and teammate Judson Stubbs got another offensive board. As the final seconds ticked away, Brent Hackett missed a 3-pointer and Murry's off-balance rebound and attempt at the buzzer came up short. TCU appeared ready to pull away when Femi Ibikunle scored inside to put the Frogs up 52-45 with 6:21 left. Moments later Prentice tipped the ball away from a TCU player. The ball was headed out of bounds, but it hit official Randy McCall and stayed inbounds and Prentice retrieved it and converted the break into a lay-up. New Mexico still trailed 54-47 with 4:20 left after Murry hit a 12-footer. Prentice, who finished with a season-high 8 points, hit a 3-pointer. Murry was called for a charging foul seconds later and Kersten hit a 3 with 3:36 remaining to cut the Frogs lead to 54-53. Prentice, who has been in and out of McKay's doghouse, played 17 solid minutes. While he hasn't gotten much playing time, Prentice has now hit 6 of 10 3s this season, none bigger than the one that kick-started the Lobos' rally. "There wasn't a lot of thinking coming off that pick," Prentice said. "I had a good screen and was open. I just put two eyes on the rim and took the shot." "It was a huge 3," McKay said. "I thought he (Prentice) played with a lot of confidence. He's been practicing hard and he's stayed with it. He had a great night individually and it will help his confidence for the second half of the season. New Mexico's Mark Walters hit one of two free throws with 2:31 left to tie it and Kersten followed with his coast-to-coast lay-up. David Chiotti led New Mexico in scoring with 12 points, nine of them in the first half. Walters scored 10.
